title: What happens if you guess? - Leigh Nataro

multiple-choice.question: What is the value of 2 to the 10th power?
When flipping a fair coin, how many possible outcomes are there?

options.label: A
options.text: Calculating exact values

options.label: B
options.text: Making predictions and determining odds

options.label: C
options.text: Analyzing data

options.label: D
options.text: Creating graphs

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: It will be around 75%

options.label: D
options.text: It will be around 100%

options.label: A
options.text: It increases

options.label: B
options.text: It decreases

options.label: C
options.text: It stays the same

options.label: D
options.text: It becomes unpredictable

options.label: A
options.text: As the number of possible outcomes increases, the probability of getting a correct answer increases

options.label: B
options.text: As the number of possible outcomes increases, the probability of getting a correct answer decreases

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: D

options.label: A

What are the three types of sources that make up the "trifecta of sourcing" in journalism?

options.label: A
options.text: Official sources, social media, and eyewitness accounts

options.label: B
options.text: Official sources, overview sources, and unofficial sources

options.label: C
options.text: Academic sources, government reports, and expert opinions

options.label: D
options.text: Primary sources, secondary sources, and tertiary sources

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary role of unofficial sources in journalism?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide factual information and data

options.label: B
options.text: To offer personal insights and explain the "why" behind an event or trend

options.label: C
options.text: To provide expert opinions and analysis

options.label: D
options.text: To serve as a primary source of information for breaking news

multiple-choice.question: What is the main purpose of using anecdotes in narrative storytelling?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide factual information and data

options.label: B
options.text: To create a more engaging and memorable narrative

options.label: C
options.text: To offer expert opinions and analysis

options.label: D
options.text: To summarize a complex issue

multiple-choice.question: Why is it essential to use a combination of different sources in journalism?

options.label: A
options.text: To create a more engaging and memorable narrative

options.label: B
options.text: To provide a well-reported piece with a diverse range of perspectives

options.label: C
options.text: To offer expert opinions and analysis

options.label: D
options.text: To increase the word count of the article

multiple-choice.question: A journalist is writing a story about a local community affected by a natural disaster. What type of sources should they seek out to create a well-reported piece?

options.label: A
options.text: Only official sources, such as government officials and experts

options.label: B
options.text: Only unofficial sources, such as eyewitness accounts and personal stories

options.label: C
options.text: A diverse range of sources, including official, overview, and unofficial sources

options.label: D
options.text: Only sources from social media and online forums

multiple-choice.question: A writer is working on a narrative story about a historical event. What technique can they use to bring life to the story?

options.label: A
options.text: Using bulleted facts and updates

options.label: B
options.text: Incorporating anecdotes and personal stories

options.label: C
options.text: Providing expert opinions and analysis

options.label: D
options.text: Creating a timeline of events

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between the three types of sources in the "trifecta of sourcing"?

options.label: A
options.text: They are mutually exclusive and should not be used together

options.label: B
options.text: They are interconnected and contribute to a well-reported piece

options.label: C
options.text: They are hierarchical, with official sources being the most important

options.label: D
options.text: They are only relevant in certain types of stories

multiple-choice.question: How do the needs of urgent reporting and narrative storytelling differ?

options.label: A
options.text: Urgent reporting requires anecdotes, while narrative storytelling requires factual information

options.label: B
options.text: Urgent reporting requires quick, factual information, while narrative storytelling benefits from anecdotes and personal stories

options.label: C
options.text: Urgent reporting and narrative storytelling have the same requirements

options.label: D
options.text: Urgent reporting is not relevant to narrative storytelling

multiple-choice.question: How can a journalist combine the concepts of the "trifecta of sourcing" and the importance of anecdotes to create a compelling narrative story?

options.label: A
options.text: By using only official sources and excluding anecdotes

options.label: B
options.text: By incorporating a diverse range of sources and using anecdotes to bring life to the story

options.label: C
options.text: By prioritizing unofficial sources and using bulleted facts and updates

options.label: D
options.text: By ignoring the "trifecta of sourcing" and focusing solely on anecdotes

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of integrating the idea of the "slow dance of information" with the need for urgent, factual reporting?

options.label: A
options.text: A more nuanced understanding of the role of narrative in journalism

options.label: B
options.text: A more simplistic understanding of the role of narrative in journalism

options.label: C
options.text: A complete rejection of the importance of narrative in journalism

options.label: D
options.text: A lack of understanding of the role of narrative in journalism

multiple-choice.question: What criteria should be used to judge the effectiveness of a journalist's use of the "trifecta of sourcing"?

options.label: A
options.text: The number of sources used

options.label: B
options.text: The diversity of sources used and the quality of the reporting

options.label: C
options.text: The speed at which the story was reported

options.label: D
options.text: The popularity of the story on social media

multiple-choice.question: How can the impact of anecdotes on the narrative of a story be evaluated?

options.label: A
options.text: By counting the number of anecdotes used

options.label: B
options.text: By assessing whether the anecdotes bring life to the story and create a more engaging narrative

options.label: C
options.text: By evaluating the accuracy of the anecdotes

options.label: D
options.text: By measuring the word count of the anecdotes

title: How fiction can change reality - Jessica Wise

multiple-choice.question: Who said, "There is no frigate like a book to take us lands away..."?

options.label: A
options.text: Jane Austen

options.label: B
options.text: Emily Dickinson

options.label: C
options.text: Charles Dickens

options.label: D
options.text: Samuel Richardson

multiple-choice.question: Which novel challenged traditional views on class and marriage in the 18th century?

options.label: A
options.text: Pride and Prejudice

options.label: B
options.text: Jane Eyre

options.label: C
options.text: Pamela

options.label: D
options.text: Twilight

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea behind the concept that stories can transport us to new worlds?

options.label: A
options.text: Stories can only provide entertainment and escapism.

options.label: B
options.text: Stories can only change our perspectives on historical events.

options.label: C
options.text: Stories can transport us to new worlds and change our perspectives on life.

options.label: D
options.text: Stories can only provide factual information.

multiple-choice.question: How did Samuel Richardson's "Pamela" impact society in the 18th century?

options.label: A
options.text: It reinforced traditional views on class and marriage.

options.label: B
options.text: It had no significant impact on society.

options.label: C
options.text: It challenged traditional views on class and marriage, sparking intense debate and inspiring counter-novels.

options.label: D
options.text: It only impacted the literary world.

multiple-choice.question: How can stories be used to promote social change?

options.label: A
options.text: By reinforcing traditional views and values.

options.label: B
options.text: By providing entertainment and escapism.

options.label: C
options.text: By challenging traditional views and promoting new perspectives through relatable characters and storylines.

options.label: D
options.text: By ignoring social issues.

multiple-choice.question: What lesson from "Pride and Prejudice" can be applied to real-life situations?

options.label: A
options.text: The importance of judging people based on their appearance.

options.label: B
options.text: The importance of considering multiple perspectives before making a decision.

options.label: C
options.text: The importance of following traditional social norms.

options.label: D
options.text: The importance of ignoring personal growth and development.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between stories and their impact on our perspectives and behaviors?

options.label: A
options.text: Stories have no impact on our perspectives and behaviors.

options.label: B
options.text: Stories can only reinforce existing perspectives and behaviors.

options.label: C
options.text: Stories can shape and change our perspectives and behaviors, influencing our understanding of the world.

options.label: D
options.text: Stories can only provide factual information.

multiple-choice.question: What is the contrast between traditional views of heroism and individualism and new, more cooperative models?

options.label: A
options.text: Traditional views emphasize cooperation, while new models emphasize individualism.

options.label: B
options.text: Traditional views emphasize individualism, while new models emphasize cooperation and shared quests.

options.label: C
options.text: Traditional views and new models are the same.

options.label: D
options.text: Traditional views are irrelevant in today's society.

multiple-choice.question: How can stories be used to promote social change and challenge traditional views?

options.label: A
options.text: By reinforcing traditional views and values.

options.label: B
options.text: By providing entertainment and escapism.

options.label: C
options.text: By challenging traditional views and promoting new perspectives through relatable characters and storylines.

options.label: D
options.text: By ignoring social issues.

multiple-choice.question: What is the concept that readers have the power to shape the stories that are told and the impact they have on society?

options.label: A
options.text: Readers have no power to shape the stories that are told.

options.label: B
options.text: Readers can only shape the stories that are told by writing their own stories.

options.label: C
options.text: Readers can shape the stories that are told by demanding diverse perspectives and representation, influencing the literary landscape.

options.label: D
options.text: Readers can only shape the stories that are told by criticizing existing stories.

multiple-choice.question: What is the importance of diverse perspectives and representation in stories?

options.label: A
options.text: Diverse perspectives and representation are not important in stories.

options.label: B
options.text: Diverse perspectives and representation are only important in non-fiction stories.

options.label: C
options.text: Diverse perspectives and representation are important in stories because they promote empathy, understanding, and a more nuanced view of the world.

options.label: D
options.text: Diverse perspectives and representation are only important in fiction stories.

multiple-choice.question: How effective are stories in promoting social change and raising awareness about global issues?

options.label: A
options.text: Stories are not effective in promoting social change and raising awareness about global issues.

options.label: B
options.text: Stories are only effective in promoting social change, but not in raising awareness about global issues.

options.label: C
options.text: Stories can be effective in promoting social change and raising awareness about global issues by inspiring empathy, action, and critical thinking.

options.label: D
options.text: Stories are only effective in raising awareness about global issues, but not in promoting social change.

multiple-choice.question: A swimmer experiences red eyes after swimming in a pool. What could be the cause, and how would you use logarithms to determine the cause?

options.label: A
options.text: The cause is the high temperature of the water, and logarithms can be used to calculate the temperature

options.label: B
options.text: The cause is the high pH of the water, and logarithms can be used to calculate the pH

options.label: C
options.text: The cause is the low volume of the water, and logarithms can be used to calculate the volume

options.label: D
options.text: The cause is the low concentration of hydrogen ions, and logarithms can be used to calculate the concentration

multiple-choice.question: How can scientific calculators be used in conjunction with logarithms to simplify calculations?

options.label: A
options.text: Scientific calculators can be used to eliminate the need for logarithms

options.label: B
options.text: Scientific calculators can be used to calculate logarithms, but not to simplify calculations

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: Why is it still important to study logarithms despite the availability of calculators?

options.label: A
options.text: Logarithms are no longer necessary with calculators

options.label: B
options.text: Logarithms are only necessary for simple calculations

options.label: C
options.text: Logarithms provide a deeper understanding of mathematical concepts and are still necessary for complex calculations

options.label: D
options.text: Logarithms are only necessary for exponential equations

multiple-choice.question: What is a limitation of using log base 10, and why is it important to understand other bases, such as log base 2?

options.label: A
options.text: Log base 10 is the only base that is useful, and other bases are not necessary

options.label: B
options.text: Log base 10 is limited to calculating pH, and other bases are necessary for other calculations

options.label: C
options.text: Log base 10 is limited to certain fields, such as chemistry, and other bases, such as log base 2, are necessary for other fields, such as computer science

options.label: D
options.text: Log base 10 is not limited, and other bases are not necessary

title: The history of keeping time - Karen Mensing

multiple-choice.question: What was the first form of telling time?

options.label: A
options.text: Hourglass

options.label: B
options.text: Sundial

options.label: C
options.text: Mechanical clock

options.label: D
options.text: Candle clock

options.label: A
options.text: Gnomon

options.label: B
options.text: Sundial

options.label: C
options.text: Hourglass

options.label: D
options.text: Obelisk

multiple-choice.question: How do sundials measure time?

options.label: A
options.text: By using a pendulum to regulate a clock

options.label: B
options.text: By casting a shadow onto a surface using a gnomon

options.label: C
options.text: By measuring the flow of water

options.label: D
options.text: By burning a candle

multiple-choice.question: What is the significant improvement in timekeeping accuracy attributed to?

options.label: A
options.text: Sundials

options.label: B
options.text: Hourglasses

options.label: C
options.text: Mechanical clocks

options.label: D
options.text: Candle clocks

multiple-choice.question: A person travels from New York to Australia and needs to adjust their clock to the local time. What is the main reason for this adjustment?

options.label: A
options.text: To avoid confusion due to different time zones

options.label: B
options.text: To account for the difference in daylight hours

options.label: C
options.text: To adjust for the change in seasons

options.label: D
options.text: To accommodate for the local language

multiple-choice.question: In areas with limited access to technology, what can be used as a backup or alternative to modern clocks?

options.label: A
options.text: Hourglasses

options.label: B
options.text: Sundials

options.label: C
options.text: Mechanical clocks

options.label: D
options.text: Candle clocks

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between sundials and mechanical clocks?

options.label: A
options.text: Sundials replaced mechanical clocks as the primary timekeeping method

options.label: B
options.text: Mechanical clocks were used to monitor the performance of sundials

options.label: C
options.text: Sundials were used to monitor the performance of clocks until the modern era

options.label: D
options.text: Mechanical clocks and sundials were used simultaneously as separate timekeeping methods

multiple-choice.question: What is the main benefit of using time zones?

options.label: A
options.text: To resolve differences in local languages

options.label: B
options.text: To account for the difference in daylight hours

options.label: C
options.text: To make communication smoother and more efficient

options.label: D
options.text: To adjust for the change in seasons

multiple-choice.question: What could be a potential innovation by combining the concept of sundials with modern technology?

options.label: A
options.text: Developing a digital sundial that uses sensors and algorithms to accurately measure time

options.label: B
options.text: Creating a system that automatically adjusts time zones for international calls

options.label: C
options.text: Designing a sculpture that incorporates sundials, hourglasses, or other ancient timekeeping devices

options.label: D
options.text: Developing a mechanical clock that uses a pendulum to regulate time

multiple-choice.question: What could be a potential solution to facilitate seamless communication across different time zones?

options.label: A
options.text: Creating a system that automatically adjusts time zones for international calls

options.label: B
options.text: Developing a digital sundial that uses sensors and algorithms to accurately measure time

options.label: C
options.text: Designing a sculpture that incorporates sundials, hourglasses, or other ancient timekeeping devices

options.label: D
options.text: Using hourglasses to measure time on board ships

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential argument for the use of time zones?

options.label: A
options.text: Time zones create confusion and disrupt communication

options.label: B
options.text: Time zones are unnecessary with the advent of modern technology

options.label: C
options.text: Time zones facilitate seamless communication and global commerce

options.label: D
options.text: Time zones are only necessary for astronomical observations

multiple-choice.question: What is a limitation of sundials as a timekeeping method?

options.label: A
options.text: Sundials are too accurate and precise

options.label: B
options.text: Sundials are not affected by the motion of a boat

options.label: C
options.text: Sundials rely on sunlight and do not work at night

options.label: D
options.text: Sundials are too complex and difficult to use
